caseTitle: OWUSU KYENKYENHENE v. J. K. ADU
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana allowed an appeal challenging the Court of Appeal's affirmation of a High Court order that awarded the appellant GHS 8,000,000 as his share of jointly owned school assets without a prior professional valuation. The parties had co-owned the Minnesota International School under a partnership agreement requiring equal sharing of assets upon dissolution. The High Court had originally ordered a professional valuation by competent experts, but none was conducted. Instead, the court relied on an inventory and financial statements that did not constitute proper valuations. The Supreme Court found the monetary award arbitrary and capricious, lacking evidentiary support, and held that the Court of Appeal erred in failing to scrutinize the record. The case was remitted to the trial court for a professional valuation to ensure fair and equitable distribution of assets in accordance with the original court order.
verdict: Appeal allowed; judgment of the Court of Appeal and High Court's award set aside; case remitted for professional valuation of assets.
citations: Order 63, rule 6 of the High Court (Civil Procedure Rules)
rationaleHighlights: No professional valuation was conducted as ordered by the High Court
The High Court's award of GHS 8,000,000 was arbitrary and capricious
Court of Appeal failed to critically examine the record
Remittal ordered for proper valuation by a professional valuer
Equal sharing of assets required per partnership agreement
Transparency and fairness in valuation emphasized
Inventory without valuation insufficient for distribution
Appellant barred from school by respondent in 1994
